FLAX & HEMP
FIBER SOLUTIONS
hero.desc: Highly specialized engineering lines that convert raw bales from the field into cleaned, standardized industrial-grade fiber.

corporate.headline: We focus only on this field. And we are the best at it.
corporate.p1: RNG Export is an engineering and trading company fully dedicated to the pre-processing, fiber preparation and cottonization of flax and hemp fibers.
corporate.p2: We do not treat flax and hemp fiber technologies as a side business in this geography. We are fully focused on this single domain.
corporate.p3: RNG Export provides high-performance machinery lines, advanced engineering support and long-term process consultancy to globally investing companies.
corporate.mission_body: To deliver fiber processing lines that are highly efficient, energy-conscious, maintenance-friendly, compliant with ATEX/Ex-Proof safety standards, modular and scalable – and to bring each investment safely into operation.
corporate.vision_body: To become one of the most trusted brands worldwide in primary fiber preparation technologies for strategic raw materials such as flax and hemp.

vision_details.title: Industrial fiber production
vision_details.description: Production of industrial-grade fibers from natural fiber sources such as flax and hemp. Through RNG Export's advanced processing technologies, various industrial products are produced in formats such as cottonized fiber, long fiber, and short fiber, starting from raw bales. These fibers are used as critical raw materials in textile, composite, nonwoven, and biocomposite sectors.

vision_details.title: Cellulose production (alpha-cellulose)
vision_details.description: Fiber processing processes optimized for high-purity alpha-cellulose production. Alpha-cellulose is a critical raw material for paper, chemical industry, and special applications. RNG Export's technology provides fiber ready for industrial cellulose production with high purity ratios and consistent quality.

vision_details.title: Nitrocellulose and defence applications
vision_details.description: High-quality fiber processing suitable for nitrocellulose production for defense industry and special applications. Nitrocellulose is a critical raw material used in propellants, explosives, and special chemical applications. Through RNG Export's rigorous quality control processes, fiber production compliant with defense industry standards is carried out.

vision_details.title: Biocomposite and bioplastic
vision_details.description: Fiber processing technologies optimized for sustainable biocomposite and bioplastic production. Biocomposites produced from natural fibers offer sustainable alternatives to synthetic materials in automotive, furniture, packaging, and construction sectors. RNG Export's fiber processing technology provides ideal raw materials for high-performance biocomposite production.

vision_details.title: Nonwoven & textile industries
vision_details.description: Fiber processing solutions specially developed for nonwoven and textile industries. Products produced in cottonized fiber, short fiber, and long fiber formats are used in hygiene, medical, filtration, cleaning, and technical textile applications. RNG Export's technology provides raw materials ready for textile production lines with high quality and homogeneous structure.

lines.section_title: Three fully integrated solutions we offer to the global market.

items.title: KENEVA – Flax & Hemp Pre-Processing Line
items.desc: The line where raw bales from the field are opened for the first time, woody parts are separated from the main fiber, impurities are removed and a stable infeed flow is created.
outputs: Opening bales without breaking their integrity
Separating shives, dust, straw and foreign material
items.benefit: Increases the efficiency of subsequent stages by 40–55%. An essential prerequisite for cellulose, biocomposite and cottonization applications.

items.title: KOTONEX – Flax & Hemp Cottonization Line
items.desc: This is the heart of the process. The cottonization line shortens the fiber length, refines and cleans the fibers, reduces weight and brings them into a cotton-like form.
outputs: Material free from metals and dust

items.title: Long Fiber Processing Line
items.desc: This line produces long fibers specifically for technical textiles, automotive composites and construction reinforcement materials.
features: Special openers preventing fiber length degradation

process.section_desc: A proven process scheme applied across all our lines for maximum efficiency.

step_details.title: Raw Bale Feeding
step_details.description: The stage where raw bales are fed into the processing line automatically or manually. Ensures regular and controlled entry of bales into the system.

step_details.title: KENEVA Pre-Opening
step_details.description: The process of opening bales and initial fiber separation. This stage is critical for increasing the efficiency of subsequent processes.

step_details.title: RODI Screening (1st Stage)
step_details.description: First stage screening process with rotary drum screen system. Dust, shives and short particles are separated.

step_details.title: Shaker Fine Cleaning
step_details.description: Fine cleaning stage with vibrating screen system. Small particles and dust are completely separated.

step_details.title: Shive / Dust Extraction
step_details.description: Removal of shives and dust particles from fibers through aspiration system. Product quality is determined at this stage.

step_details.title: Metal Detection
step_details.description: Detection and removal of metal particles in fibers through metal detector system. Critical stage for machine safety.

step_details.title: Cottonization Unit
step_details.description: Critical stage where fibers are converted to cotton-like form. Fibers are refined and standardized through multi-stage carding system.

step_details.title: Long Fiber Unit
step_details.description: Special unit where 6-40 cm long fibers are processed while preserving their length. Optimized for technical textile and composite applications.

step_details.title: Final Stabilization
step_details.description: Final quality control and stabilization stage of processed fibers. Product standardization is achieved.

step_details.title: Bale Pressing
step_details.description: Baling of processed fibers with automatic pressing system. High-density, transport-ready bales are created.

outputs.title: COTTONIZED FIBER
outputs.desc: Industrial-grade fiber in a cotton-like form.

outputs.title: CLEANED LONG FIBER
outputs.desc: Long fibers optimized for technical textile and composite applications.

outputs.title: SHORT FIBER
outputs.desc: Standardized short fibers for nonwovens and biocomposites.

output_details.title: COTTONIZED FIBER
output_details.description: Premium industrial-grade processed fiber transformed from flax and hemp fibers into cotton-like form through RNG Export's advanced multi-stage carding system. This product undergoes a sophisticated refinement and standardization process, acquiring cotton-like structure and feel. With high purity ratios and homogeneous fiber distribution, it is ready for critical industrial applications such as nonwoven, yarn, biocomposite, and cellulose production. Manufactured using RNG Export's advanced cottonization technology, this fiber offers a sustainable and eco-friendly alternative, playing a pioneering role in textile and composite sectors.
features: Homogeneous fiber distribution and standardized size
Optimized for nonwoven and yarn production
Suitable for biocomposite and cellulose applications
Low moisture content and stable structure
Completely free from metal and dust

output_details.title: CLEANED LONG FIBER
output_details.description: Premium product specially optimized for technical textile and composite applications, processed while preserving the integrity of 6-40 cm long fibers. Thanks to RNG Export's advanced long fiber processing technology, natural fiber strength and durability are preserved while completely removing metal particles and dust. This product offers a sustainable alternative to glass fiber and synthetic fibers, used in the production of high-performance composite materials in automotive, aerospace, construction, and maritime sectors. With homogeneous quality and consistent fiber length distribution, it provides a reliable raw material that meets industrial standards.
features: Completely free from metal and dust
Homogeneous quality and consistent fiber distribution
Low moisture content and stable structure

output_details.title: SHORT FIBER
output_details.description: Specially standardized, high-quality processed short fiber for nonwoven and biocomposite sectors. Through RNG Export's rigorous quality control processes, it is produced in industrial-ready format with homogeneous size distribution and consistent quality. This product has a wide range of applications including filling materials, insulation products, and packaging industry. With high absorbent properties and eco-friendly structure, it is a preferred raw material in sustainable production processes. Thanks to standardized size and homogeneous distribution, it can be processed smoothly in production lines and provides consistent results.
applications: Garden and agricultural applications (mulch, soil improvement)

machinesSection.section_desc: Nine core units engineered specifically for flax and hemp processing.

items.name: KENEVA – Fiber Pre-Processing Unit
items.description: The first major unit receiving input from raw bales. It opens the bale without destroying integrity, reduces large fractions, and separates fiber from the core to ensure stable intake flow.
features: Automatic control system stabilizing feed density

detailSpecs.Function: Bale opening, fiber shredding, coarse carding

items.name: Fiber Cottonization Machine
items.description: Performs the final and most critical transformation of the fiber. It refines fibers, stabilizes length, and brings them into a 'cotton-like' form. Produces the 'gold standard' raw material for cellulose, NC, biocomposite, yarn, and nonwoven production.

items.name: Long Fiber Processing Unit
items.description: Processes flax/hemp long fibers (6–40 cm) while preserving their structure. Operates with special openers preventing fiber breakage and low-speed controlled carding drums.

items.name: RODI – Rotary Drum Screen
items.description: Critical screening technology used at every stage of flax and hemp processes. Separates dust, shives, and short particles from the fiber, determining product quality.

items.name: Vertical Bale Press
items.description: Compact packaging solution for short fiber, cottonized fiber, and long fiber. Creates high-density bales with automatic compression.

items.name: Horizontal Bale Press
items.description: High-volume press system preferred by large-capacity facilities, suitable for continuous feeding.
features: Automatic wire tying or steel strap option

items.name: Aspiration Unit
items.description: The brain of the entire line; collects dust, light particles, and fiber fly. Maintains facility air quality and ensures ATEX safety. Multi-stage aspiration system captures dust and particles at each processing point. Cyclone and bag filter combination effectively separates both heavy and fine particles. Frequency inverter-controlled fans automatically adjust flow rate according to line load, optimizing energy consumption and preventing filter overload.

items.name: Magnetic Detector
items.description: Protects the entire line and machines by separating metal parts coming from raw material. Critical for the safety of RODI and cottonization units. Multi-stage magnetic and sensor-based detection system detects iron, stainless steel, and other metal particles within milliseconds. When metal is detected, the line automatically stops and the operator is alerted. This protects blades, drums, and other sensitive equipment, guarantees product quality, and minimizes ATEX safety risks.
features: Continuous monitoring with metal density sensor

items.name: Shaker Unit
items.description: Fine cleaning and separation machine that determines the final form of the fiber, separating remaining shives and sawdust. With multi-stage vibrating screen system, it ensures separation of even the smallest particles in the fiber. Thanks to anti-blinding technology, screens remain continuously open and cleaning efficiency does not drop. Integrated operation with aspiration system guarantees complete removal of dust and light particles.

items.name: Pellet Machine
items.description: Converts production waste or by-products into pellet form.

items.name: Seed Screening Unit
items.description: Used for separating and cleaning seeds after harvest. Multi-stage screening system ensures precise separation of seeds of different sizes. Automatic removal of dust, foreign matter, and damaged seeds guarantees high-quality seed production. Adjustable screen openings allow optimization for flax, hemp, and other oilseeds. Integrated aspiration system captures dust and light particles at source, ensuring clean and quality seed production.

blog.label: BLOG
blog.heading: Engineering Insights on Hemp & Flax Fiber
blog.subheading: Field-proven tips on cottonization, long fiber stability, turnkey plants and quality optimization.

hemp-line-optimization.title: Optimizing Hemp Lines: The Golden Rules of Cottonization
hemp-line-optimization.excerpt: Removing moisture, dust and metal before cottonization boosts throughput up to 30%. Which sensors and drum speeds matter most?
hemp-line-optimization.content: Three critical parameters define cottonization yield: inlet moisture (8–12%), drum speed and aspiration flow. Sensor-based density control keeps the line stable and trims energy use.
hemp-line-optimization.long_content:
In industrial hemp processing facilities, the most critical way to increase efficiency is to standardize the quality of the material entering the cottonization line. Our field experience at RNG Export shows that capacity increases of up to 30% are achieved not just by increasing machine speed, but by optimizing the process.

Rule One: Inlet Moisture. The moisture content of the fiber entering the cottonization unit must be between 8% and 12%. Fiber that is too dry breaks and turns into dust; fiber that is too moist wraps around drums and causes blockages. We use sensors that continuously measure moisture at the line inlet and automatic humidification units to maintain this balance.

Rule Two: Drum Speed and Blade Geometry. Every hemp variety is different. Drum revolutions per minute (RPM) must be dynamically adjustable via PLC according to fiber strength. On RNG Export lines, operators can optimize machine settings in seconds by running recipe-based production during raw material changes.

Rule Three: Aspiration Flow. Removing micro-dust and short fibers released during cottonization is vital for both product quality and ATEX safety. Insufficient suction causes fibers to re-agglomerate (nep formation). RNG Export aspiration units save energy and offer maximum cleaning by adjusting flow rates as needed thanks to frequency inverter fans.

flax-turnkey-factory.title: Turnkey Flax Fiber Plant: A Practical Guide
flax-turnkey-factory.excerpt: Flax stalk breaking, shive control and long fiber protection: ATEX safety, aspiration layout, and post-baling logistics.
flax-turnkey-factory.content: Biggest loss in flax lines is fiber breakage and shive density fluctuation. Low-torque openers, fine shaker screening and automatic bale pressing deliver homogeneous density.
flax-turnkey-factory.long_content:
Setting up a flax processing plant requires integrated process engineering, not just lining up machines. Every step from the arrival of bales from the field to the shipment of processed fiber must be planned.

1. Decortication (Stalk Breaking and Pre-Opening): Separating the woody part (shive) of the flax stalk from the fiber begins with a mechanical breaking process. The critical part here is to break the woody part without shortening the fiber length. RNG Export's KENEVA series openers ensure maximum shive separation without damaging the fiber thanks to special blade angles.

2. Fine Cleaning (Scutching & Shaking): Multi-deck shaker systems are used to clean remaining small woody particles. Thanks to our anti-blinding technology, screens remain continuously open and cleaning efficiency does not drop.

3. ATEX and Safety: Flax dust is highly flammable. The facility's aspiration system and electrical panels must comply with ATEX standards. RNG Export offers spark detection and automatic suppression systems as standard.

4. Logistics and Baling: Processed flax fiber is voluminous. High-density bale presses are used to reduce transport costs. Our fully automatic presses speed up your logistics operation by working with a capacity of up to 5 tons per hour.

long-fiber-composites.title: Long Fiber for Composites: Automotive-Grade Flax & Hemp
long-fiber-composites.excerpt: Preserving 6–40 cm fibers is critical for lightweight alternatives to glass fiber. How stabilization and metal detection affect surface quality.
long-fiber-composites.content: With low-speed controlled drums and anti-blinding shakers, fiber integrity is preserved, tensile strength rises, and biocomposites gain better surface quality.
long-fiber-composites.long_content:
The automotive industry is turning to natural fibers instead of glass fiber to reduce vehicle weight and carbon footprint. Flax and hemp are the strongest candidates with their high strength-to-weight ratio. However, the fiber to be used in composite production must meet certain standards.

Fiber Length: The main factor providing strength in composite materials is fiber length. RNG Export's long fiber lines process fibers between 6-40 cm while preserving them. By avoiding aggressive openers, the natural structure of the fiber is not disrupted.

Metal and Foreign Matter: A metal particle in injection or pressing molds can lead to disaster. Therefore, our lines feature multi-stage magnetic detectors and metal separators. We guarantee 100% metal-free fiber.

Homogeneity: In composite part production, the fiber must be distributed evenly within the mold. Our KOTONEX technology prevents clumping by individualizing fibers and facilitates resin impregnation.

Door panels, dashboard bodies, and interior trim parts produced with this technology possess both lightweight and impact-absorbing properties.

hemp-dust-control.title: Dust & ATEX Control in Hemp Lines: Aspiration Tips
hemp-dust-control.excerpt: Cut dust, sparks, and fiber loss with multi-stage aspiration and sensor-based airflow. Which filter, which fan?
hemp-dust-control.content: Fine dust and metal particles reduce both quality and safety. The right cyclone, bag filter, and VFD fan combo is critical.
hemp-dust-control.long_content:
Dust management in hemp processing is as much about safety (ATEX) as it is about product quality. Key principles we use at RNG Export:

1) Multi-Stage Aspiration: Separate aspiration after bale opening, decortication, and cottonization. Dust and short fibers are captured at the source, not returned to the line.

2) Sensor-Based Flow Control: VFD-driven fans adjust airflow to line load. This lowers energy use and prevents filter overload.

3) Cyclone + Bag Filter: Cyclone captures heavy particles; bag filter traps fine dust. ATEX safety valves and spark detection modules minimize fire risk.

4) Metal Separation: Magnetic detectors and separators reduce metal risk in dust, protecting knives and ensuring product safety.

flax-quality-control.title: Flax Fiber Quality Control: Moisture, Shive, and Metal
flax-quality-control.excerpt: Operator recipes, online moisture sensors, and metal separation keep flax lines consistent. Which metric at which step?
flax-quality-control.content: Three metrics define flax quality: moisture, shive ratio, and metal contamination. Inline sensors and recipe-based runs are key.
flax-quality-control.long_content:
In flax fiber production, fluctuating quality raises rejection risk. RNG Export lines monitor key metrics:

1) Moisture Management: Online sensors keep 8–12% band. Over-dry fiber creates dust; over-wet fiber wraps drums. Humidification/drying adjusts per recipe.

2) Shive Control: After shaker + aspiration, shive ratio is measured inline. If out of band, line speed and airflow self-optimize.

3) Metal & Foreign Matter: Multi-stage magnets and metal separators improve machine life and product safety—protecting card wires and blades.

4) Recipe-Based Production: Operators pick predefined recipes per raw material source. Keeps quality stable and shortens changeover.

hemp-metal-detection.title: Metal Separation in Hemp Lines: Blade Life & Safety
hemp-metal-detection.excerpt: Use multi-stage magnets and separators after decortication to extend blade life and cut spark risk.
hemp-metal-detection.content: Metal contamination drives knife wear and spark risk. Multi-stage magnetic separation with sensor alerts is critical.
hemp-metal-detection.long_content:
Metal particles in hemp/flax lines shorten knife life, reduce product quality, and raise ATEX risk. Our approach:

1) Multi-Stage Magnets: At bale opener and decorticator outlets; second stage before card wires and drums.

2) Metal Separator: Inline in aspiration; sensor-driven ejection removes metal from flow.

3) Sensor & Alarm: When metal density crosses threshold, line speed is reduced and operators are alerted to check knives.

4) Spark Risk: Metal + dust increases spark risk; ATEX valves and spark detection modules are integrated.

flax-energy-optimization.title: Energy Optimization in Flax Lines: Fans, Drying, Automation
flax-energy-optimization.excerpt: Cut energy up to 18% with VFD fans, moisture-driven drying, and recipe-based speed control.
flax-energy-optimization.content: Energy load concentrates in drying, aspiration, and drive motors. VFDs and sensors make the difference.
flax-energy-optimization.long_content:
Energy cost is a major share in flax/hemp operations. Key optimizations we deploy:

1) Aspiration Fans: VFD fans adjust flow to line load; filter differential pressure drives automatic modes.

2) Drying: Moisture sensors prevent over-drying below target band; quality is preserved while energy drops.

3) Automation / Recipes: Pre-set profiles for speed, temperature, and airflow per material; faster changeover.

4) Energy Monitoring: Line-level kWh tracking and reporting for peak demand management and maintenance planning.

hemp-processing-checklist.title: Hemp Processing Line Installation Checklist: Step-by-Step Guide
hemp-processing-checklist.excerpt: Critical points in hemp processing plant installation: space planning, machine selection, ATEX compliance, and operational readiness.
hemp-processing-checklist.content: Hemp processing line installation requires integrated systems engineering, not just machine assembly. This checklist covers critical steps for successful installation.
hemp-processing-checklist.long_content:
Hemp processing line installation is a complex process that transforms raw bales from the field into industrial-grade fiber. RNG Export's 20 years of experience shows that successful installations follow a specific methodology.

1. SPACE PLANNING AND INFRASTRUCTURE

Factory space calculation: Minimum 800 m² for 1 ton/hour capacity, 2500 m² for 5 ton/hour. Minimum height of 6 meters is critical. Bale storage area should be 1.5 times the line length.

Electrical infrastructure: Hemp processing lines consume high power. 150-200 kW for 1 ton/hour, 600-800 kW for 5 ton/hour. ATEX-compliant electrical panels and grounding system are mandatory.

2. MACHINE SELECTION AND CONFIGURATION

Bale opening unit: Automatic bale feeding, metal detector, and pre-cleaning units should be standard. RNG Export's RODI series operates up to 5 tons/hour capacity.

Decorticator selection: Blade angle and RPM should be adjustable based on hemp stalk hardness. KENEVA series decorticators provide flexible production with inverter-controlled motors.

Cottonization line: Number of drums, blade geometry, and aspiration flow rate directly affect product quality. RNG Export lines can process different hemp varieties with recipe-based automation.

3. ATEX AND SAFETY

Dust explosion risk: Hemp dust is highly flammable. All aspiration systems must be ATEX Zone 22 compliant. Spark detection and automatic suppression systems are mandatory.

Electrical safety: All motors and electrical panels must be IP65 protection class and ATEX certified. RNG Export designs all systems according to ATEX standards.

4. OPERATIONAL READINESS

Operator training: Machine operators must be trained on PLC interface, recipe management, and emergency procedures. RNG Export provides 5 days of operator training with every installation.

Maintenance planning: Preventive maintenance program extends machine life and prevents unplanned downtime. Blade replacement, filter cleaning, and lubrication schedules are critical.

5. QUALITY CONTROL AND TESTING

Initial production tests: 72-hour continuous test production should be performed after installation. Moisture, shive ratio, metal contamination, and fiber length should be measured.

Performance guarantee: RNG Export provides capacity and quality guarantees for all lines. If target performance is not reached, optimization and adjustment service is provided free of charge.

flax-fiber-production-line.title: Flax Fiber Production Line Optimization: Efficiency and Quality Tips
flax-fiber-production-line.excerpt: Critical parameters to increase efficiency in flax fiber production line: stalk breaking, fiber protection, shive separation, and moisture management.
flax-fiber-production-line.content: Flax fiber production line requires a delicate process. Optimized machine settings are critical to prevent fiber breakage and maintain quality.
flax-fiber-production-line.long_content:
Flax fiber production requires a more delicate process than hemp. Flax fibers are finer and more brittle, so aggressive processing techniques should be avoided. RNG Export's flax lines maintain fiber integrity while maximizing efficiency.

1. STALK BREAKING AND DECORTICATION

Low-speed openers: In flax stalk breaking, woody parts (shives) must be separated without damaging the fiber. RNG Export's KENEVA series openers operate at 400-600 RPM range to preserve fiber length.

Blade angle optimization: Specially designed blade angles for flax minimize fiber breakage. Operators can adjust blade angle via PLC based on raw material quality.

2. FIBER PROTECTION AND LENGTH MANAGEMENT

Long fiber line: Preservation of 6-40 cm long fibers is critical for composite and textile applications. RNG Export's long fiber lines preserve fiber integrity with low-speed drums and anti-blinding shaker systems.

Short fiber separation: Short fibers (2-6 cm) are directed to cottonization line. This way both long and short fibers are utilized and waste is minimized.

3. SHIVE SEPARATION AND CLEANING

Multi-stage shaker systems: 3-5 stage shaker systems are used to clean remaining small woody particles (shives). Anti-blinding technology keeps screens continuously open.

Aspiration optimization: Separate aspiration units at each stage capture shives and dust at source. VFD fans adjust flow rate based on line load.

4. MOISTURE MANAGEMENT

Target moisture band: Ideal moisture content for flax fiber is 8-12%. Too dry fiber produces dust, too moist fiber wraps around drums and causes blockages.

Online moisture sensors: Moisture sensors placed along the line provide continuous measurement. Humidification/drying units activate automatically.

5. QUALITY CONTROL AND STANDARDIZATION

Inline measurements: Shive ratio, moisture, metal contamination, and fiber length are continuously measured. When outside target band, line speed and machine settings are automatically optimized.

Recipe-based production: Pre-defined recipes for different flax varieties are used. This maintains quality standard while reducing changeover time.

6. ENERGY EFFICIENCY

VFD-controlled motors: All drive motors operate with frequency inverters. Speed adjustment based on line load reduces energy consumption by 15-20%.

Smart aspiration: Fan speed is automatically adjusted based on filter differential pressure. Unnecessary high flow is prevented, energy is saved.

decorticator-selection-guide.title: Decorticator Machine Selection Guide: Criteria for Hemp and Flax
decorticator-selection-guide.excerpt: What to consider in decorticator selection: capacity, blade system, motor power, and raw material compatibility. Which decorticator for which application?
decorticator-selection-guide.content: The decorticator is the heart of hemp and flax processing lines. Correct decorticator selection determines both product quality and line efficiency.
decorticator-selection-guide.long_content:
The decorticator machine is a critical unit that separates the woody part (shive) of hemp and flax stalks from the fiber. Wrong selection leads to fiber loss, low quality, and high maintenance costs. This RNG Export guide covers critical criteria for correct decorticator selection.

1. CAPACITY CALCULATION

Hourly capacity: Decorticator capacity determines the total line capacity. 800-1000 kg/hour decorticator capacity is required for 1 ton/hour raw bale. RNG Export decorticators scale from 500 kg/hour to 5 tons/hour.

Continuity factor: There can be a 20-30% difference between theoretical and actual capacity. Raw material quality, moisture content, and maintenance downtime create this difference. 30% reserve should be left for safe capacity selection.

2. BLADE SYSTEM AND ADJUSTABILITY

Blade angle: 15-25° for hemp, 10-18° for flax is optimal. Adjustable blade angle provides flexibility to process different raw material qualities.

Number and arrangement of blades: Multi-blade systems provide more homogeneous separation but consume more energy. RNG Export decorticators come with 8-16 blade configurations.

Blade change ease: Quick blade replacement shortens maintenance time. RNG Export's modular blade system enables 30-minute blade change.

3. MOTOR POWER AND DRIVE SYSTEM

Power requirement: 30-40 kW motor power is required for 1 ton/hour capacity. Hemp requires higher power than flax. RNG Export decorticators come with inverter-controlled motors.

Soft start: Inverter-controlled motors provide soft start. This prevents load on electrical grid and extends machine life.

4. RAW MATERIAL COMPATIBILITY

Hemp vs Flax: Hemp is harder, requires higher crushing power. Flax is more delicate, requires lower RPM and gentle processing. RNG Export decorticators have flexibility to process both products.

Moisture tolerance: Moisture content of raw material entering decorticator should be 8-15%. Too dry material causes fiber breakage, too moist material causes blockages.

5. CLEANING EFFICIENCY AND FIBER LOSS

Shive separation ratio: A good decorticator should provide 80-90% shive separation without breaking the fiber. RNG Export decorticators offer maximum cleaning with minimum fiber loss thanks to optimized blade geometry.

Fiber length preservation: For long fiber applications, preserving fiber length is critical. Low-speed, adjustable blade angle systems should be preferred.

6. MAINTENANCE AND SERVICE

Accessibility: Easy access to blades, screens, and drive systems shortens maintenance time. RNG Export decorticators enable quick maintenance thanks to modular design.

Spare parts supply time: Quick supply of critical spare parts (blades, screens, bearings) is important. RNG Export keeps all spare parts in stock.

7. AUTOMATION AND CONTROL

PLC integration: Decorticator should be integrable to line automation. Speed, blade angle, and feed rate should be controllable via PLC.

Recipe management: Pre-defined recipes for different raw material types enable quick changeover. RNG Export's recipe system minimizes operator errors.

hemp-flax-machinery-comparison.title: Hemp and Flax Processing Machinery Comparison: Differences and Similarities
hemp-flax-machinery-comparison.excerpt: Technical differences between hemp and flax processing machinery: RPM, blade angles, power requirements, and process optimization.
hemp-flax-machinery-comparison.content: Hemp and flax are plants with different processing requirements despite similar appearance. This comparison facilitates optimal machine selection for both products.
hemp-flax-machinery-comparison.long_content:
Hemp and flax are both plants used for fiber production but have different processing requirements. RNG Export's 20 years of experience has enabled development of flexible systems that can process both products on a single line. This comparison details technical differences and common points.

1. FIBER PROPERTIES AND PROCESSING DIFFICULTY

Hemp: Has harder and more durable fiber structure. Average fiber length is 1-5 meters. Has higher strength/weight ratio but is harder to process.

Flax: Has finer and more delicate fiber structure. Average fiber length is 30-90 cm. Easier to process but brittle, aggressive processing techniques should be avoided.

2. DECORTICATOR DIFFERENCES

RPM: 600-900 RPM for hemp, 400-600 RPM for flax is optimal. High RPM for flax leads to fiber breakage.

Blade angles: 15-25° for hemp, 10-18° blade angle is used. Smaller angle for flax is critical for fiber protection.

Motor power: 40-50 kW for 1 ton/hour capacity for hemp, 30-40 kW for flax. Hemp requires higher crushing power.

3. COTTONIZATION DIFFERENCES

Drum speed: 800-1200 RPM for hemp, 600-900 RPM for flax is optimal. High speed for flax causes fiber breakage.

Blade geometry: More aggressive blade geometry for hemp, gentler angles for flax. RNG Export's adjustable blade systems can process both products.

Aspiration flow rate: Hemp produces more dust, so higher aspiration flow rate is required. Lower flow is sufficient for flax.

4. MOISTURE MANAGEMENT

Target moisture band: 8-12% moisture is optimal for both products but flax requires narrower band (9-11%). Moisture control is more critical for flax.

Drying time: Hemp has higher moisture tolerance. Drying for flax must be more delicate, over-drying reduces fiber quality.

5. CLEANING AND QUALITY CONTROL

Shive separation: 85-90% for hemp, 80-85% for flax is targeted. Flax produces finer shives, cleaning is more difficult.

Metal detection: Multi-stage metal detectors are critical for both products. More sensitive detectors are required for flax because even small metal particles reduce fiber quality.

6. ENERGY CONSUMPTION

Total power: Hemp lines consume higher power (200-250 kW for 1 ton/hour), flax lines lower (150-200 kW for 1 ton/hour). Difference comes from power requirements in decorticator and cottonization units.

Inverter optimization: VFD-controlled motors are critical for both lines. Inverter optimization provides greater energy savings in flax lines because they operate at lower speeds.

7. MAINTENANCE AND SERVICE

Blade life: Blade life is shorter for hemp (300-500 hours), longer for flax (500-800 hours). Hemp is harder material so blade wear is higher.

Filter cleaning: Hemp produces more dust, filter cleaning must be done more frequently. Less dust is produced for flax but filter selection is critical because dust is finer.

8. FLEXIBILITY FOR PROCESSING ON SINGLE LINE

RNG Export's hybrid lines: Thanks to adjustable blade angles, inverter-controlled motors, and recipe-based automation, the same line can process both hemp and flax. Changeover time is 2-4 hours.

Recipe management: Operators select pre-defined recipes based on raw material type. PLC automatically optimizes machine settings. This maintains both flexibility and quality.

fiber-plant-cost-analysis.title: Fiber Processing Plant Installation Cost: Detailed Analysis and Feasibility
fiber-plant-cost-analysis.excerpt: Hemp and flax fiber processing plant installation costs: machine investment, infrastructure, automation level, and operating costs.
fiber-plant-cost-analysis.content: Fiber processing plant installation cost varies based on capacity, automation level, and selected machine configuration. This analysis provides critical data for investment planning.
fiber-plant-cost-analysis.long_content:
Hemp and flax fiber processing plant installation is a significant investment. Correct planning and cost analysis are critical for a successful project. This RNG Export analysis covers different capacity and configuration options.

1. MACHINE INVESTMENT

Starter line (1 ton/hour): Basic line configuration - bale opening, decorticator, aspiration, cottonization, drying, and pressing. Machine investment: €250,000 - €350,000.

Medium-scale line (2-3 tons/hour): Advanced configuration - long fiber line, multi-stage cleaning, metal detection, automation. Machine investment: €450,000 - €650,000.

Large-scale line (5 tons/hour): Fully automated integrated facility - all units, SCADA system, energy optimization, quality control systems. Machine investment: €850,000 - €1,200,000.

2. INFRASTRUCTURE AND CONSTRUCTION

Factory building: 800 m² for 1 ton/hour, 2500 m² for 5 tons/hour closed area required. Construction cost (Turkey): €400-600/m². Total: €320,000 - €1,500,000.

Electrical infrastructure: Transformer, panel, cabling. 150-200 kW for 1 ton/hour, 600-800 kW for 5 tons/hour power. Infrastructure cost: €50,000 - €200,000.

ATEX compliance: Special electrical panels, spark detection systems for explosive atmosphere compliance. Additional cost: €30,000 - €80,000.

3. AUTOMATION LEVEL

Basic automation: PLC control, basic recipe management. Additional cost: €20,000 - €40,000.

Advanced automation: SCADA system, energy monitoring, quality control integration. Additional cost: €60,000 - €120,000.

Full automation: AI-supported optimization, predictive maintenance, cloud integration. Additional cost: €150,000 - €250,000.

4. OPERATING COSTS

Energy: Monthly €8,000-12,000 for 1 ton/hour, €35,000-50,000 for 5 tons/hour. 15-20% savings with inverter optimization.

Labor: 1 operator per shift, 9 operators for 3 shifts. Monthly labor cost: €15,000-25,000.

Maintenance and spare parts: 3-5% of annual machine investment. €7,500-17,500/year for 1 ton/hour, €25,500-60,000/year for 5 tons/hour.

5. PAYBACK PERIOD

Capacity utilization: Assuming 80% capacity utilization, 576 tons/month for 1 ton/hour, 2880 tons/month for 5 tons/hour production.

Product price: Difference between processed fiber price (€/ton) and raw material cost (€/ton) determines profit margin. Average profit margin: €200-400/ton.

Payback: 18-30 months for 1 ton/hour, 24-36 months for 5 tons/hour payback period (depending on capacity utilization and profit margin).

6. HIDDEN COSTS

Logistics: Bale transport, processed fiber shipment. Monthly cost: €5,000-15,000.

Quality control laboratory: Moisture, shive ratio, fiber length measurement equipment. Investment: €20,000-40,000.

Training: Operator and maintenance personnel training. First year: €10,000-20,000.

7. FINANCING OPTIONS

Credit: Up to 50% grant support available from institutions like KOSGEB, TKDK in Turkey. Credit interest rates: 8-12%/year.

Leasing: Payment can be spread over 36-60 months with machine leasing. Monthly payment: 2.5-3.5% of machine investment.

8. RNG EXPORT SUPPORT

Feasibility study: Free feasibility study and cost analysis. Our engineers prepare detailed report specific to your project.

Financing consultancy: Consultancy service for KOSGEB, TKDK applications. Support during application process.

Warranty and service: 2-year warranty on all machines, 24/7 technical support. Planned maintenance service with maintenance agreements.

flax-stalk-processing.title: Flax Stalk Processing Technologies: Shive Separation and Fiber Protection
flax-stalk-processing.excerpt: Critical technologies in flax stalk processing: decortication, shive separation, fiber length preservation, and dust management. Which machines are used?
flax-stalk-processing.content: Flax stalk processing requires separation of fiber from woody part (shive). Correct technology selection determines both fiber quality and efficiency.
flax-stalk-processing.long_content:
Flax stalk processing is the first and most critical stage of flax fiber production. Flax stalks from the field are processed to separate woody part (shive) from fiber. During this process, fiber integrity must be preserved and maximum shive separation must be achieved. RNG Export's flax stalk processing technologies optimize these goals.

1. FLAX STALK PROPERTIES

Structure: Flax stalk consists of outer fiber layer and inner woody part (shive). Fibers are arranged longitudinally on outer surface of stalk. Average stalk diameter 1-3 mm, length 60-120 cm.

Moisture content: Moisture content of flax stalk after harvest is 12-18%. Must be reduced to 8-12% before processing. Too dry stalk causes fiber breakage.

2. DECORTICATION PROCESS

Pre-breaking: Flax stalks first pass through low-speed breakers for pre-processing. At this stage, stalk structure is loosened but fiber integrity is preserved. RNG Export's pre-breaking units operate at 300-400 RPM range.

Main decortication: After pre-breaking, stalks are fed to main decorticator. At this stage, shive is separated from fiber. Specially designed blade angles (10-18°) and low speed (400-600 RPM) for flax are used.

Blade geometry: Special blade geometry for flax breaks shive without damaging fiber. Blade angle must be adjustable because different flax varieties require different angles.

3. SHIVE SEPARATION TECHNOLOGIES

Shaker systems: Remaining small shive particles after decortication are cleaned with multi-stage shaker (vibrating) systems. 3-5 stage shaker systems separate shive particles of different sizes.

Anti-blinding technology: Flax dust can clog screens (blinding). RNG Export's anti-blinding technology keeps screens continuously open. This way cleaning efficiency does not drop.

Aspiration: Separate aspiration units at each stage capture shives and dust at source. VFD fans adjust flow rate based on line load.

4. FIBER LENGTH PRESERVATION

Low-speed processing: Flax fibers are brittle, aggressive processing techniques should be avoided. Low-speed drums (400-600 RPM) and gentle blade angles preserve fiber length.

Long fiber line: 6-40 cm long fibers are directed to special long fiber line. This line preserves fiber integrity with low-speed drums and anti-blinding shaker systems.

Short fiber utilization: 2-6 cm short fibers are directed to cottonization line. This way both long and short fibers are utilized and waste is minimized.

5. DUST MANAGEMENT AND ATEX

Dust production: Fine dust is released during flax processing. This dust creates both health and safety risks. ATEX Zone 22 compliant aspiration systems are mandatory.

Spark detection: Flax dust is flammable. Spark detection and automatic suppression systems minimize fire risk. RNG Export designs all systems according to ATEX standards.

Filter selection: Flax dust is very fine, requires special filters. Bag filters capture dust with 99.9%+ efficiency.

6. MOISTURE MANAGEMENT

Target moisture band: Ideal moisture content for flax stalk processing is 8-12%. Too dry stalk causes fiber breakage. Too moist stalk wraps around drums and causes blockages.

Online moisture sensors: Moisture sensors placed along the line provide continuous measurement. Humidification/drying units activate automatically.

7. QUALITY CONTROL

Shive ratio measurement: Shive ratio in processed fiber must be continuously measured. Target: below 5% shive. High shive ratio reduces product quality.

Fiber length analysis: Fiber length is critical for long fiber applications. Online measurement systems continuously monitor fiber length.

Metal contamination: Metal particles reduce both machine life and product quality. Multi-stage magnetic detectors are mandatory.

8. EFFICIENCY OPTIMIZATION

Capacity: Flax stalk processing line capacity is determined by decorticator capacity. 800-1000 kg/hour decorticator capacity is required for 1 ton/hour raw stalk.

Energy optimization: VFD-controlled motors reduce energy consumption by 15-20% by adjusting speed based on line load.

Recipe-based production: Pre-defined recipes for different flax varieties enable quick changeover and optimal quality.

hemp-peeling-machine.title: Hemp Peeling Machine Technical Specifications and Applications
hemp-peeling-machine.excerpt: What to consider in hemp peeling machine selection: capacity, blade system, motor power, and process integration. RNG Export's KENEVA series.
hemp-peeling-machine.content: Hemp peeling machine is a critical unit that separates outer fiber layer of hemp stalk. Correct selection determines both product quality and line efficiency.
hemp-peeling-machine.long_content:
Hemp peeling machine is a special type of decorticator that separates outer fiber layer of hemp stalk from inner woody part (shive). Hemp requires special design because it has harder structure than flax. RNG Export's KENEVA series peeling machines are optimized for hemp processing.

1. HEMP PEELING MACHINE OPERATING PRINCIPLE

Mechanical separation: Hemp stalk contacts blades on rotating drums. Blades separate outer fiber layer from inner woody part. This operation must be done preserving fiber integrity.

Blade angle: Optimal blade angle for hemp is 15-25°. This angle provides maximum separation without damaging fiber. Adjustable blade angle provides flexibility to process different hemp varieties.

RPM: Optimal RPM for hemp peeling is 600-900. High RPM causes fiber breakage. Low RPM causes insufficient separation.

2. TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS

Capacity: RNG Export's KENEVA series peeling machines are produced in capacities from 500 kg/hour to 5 tons/hour. Capacity selection should be made based on total line capacity.

Motor power: 40-50 kW motor power is required for 1 ton/hour capacity. Hemp requires higher power than flax. Inverter-controlled motors provide soft start and energy savings.

Number of blades: Configurations with 8-16 blades available. Multi-blade systems provide more homogeneous separation but consume more energy.

Drum diameter: Drum diameters from 600-1200 mm available. Large drum provides higher capacity but requires higher power.

3. BLADE SYSTEM

Blade material: High carbon steel or carbide-coated blades used. Blade wear is high because hemp is hard material. Carbide-coated blades extend life 2-3 times.

Blade replacement: Thanks to modular blade system, blades can be quickly replaced. Blade change time: 30-45 minutes.

Blade angle adjustment: Blade angle can be adjusted via PLC. This enables optimal setting for different hemp varieties.

4. PROCESS INTEGRATION

Bale opening integration: Peeling machine is placed after bale opening unit. Automatic feeding system provides continuous production.

Aspiration integration: Dust and short fibers released during peeling are removed with aspiration system. Source capture principle prevents dust return to main line.

Metal detection: Metal detectors before and after peeling prevent metal contamination. This preserves both machine life and product quality.

5. QUALITY PARAMETERS

Fiber loss: A good peeling machine should provide maximum separation with minimum fiber loss. RNG Export's KENEVA series provides 85-90% separation with 3-5% fiber loss.

Fiber length preservation: Preserving fiber length is critical for long fiber applications. Optimized blade angles and low speed preserve fiber length.

Shive separation ratio: Shive ratio in processed fiber should be below 5%. High shive ratio reduces product quality.

6. MAINTENANCE AND SERVICE

Preventive maintenance: Blades should be replaced every 300-500 hours. Bearings should be checked every 2000 hours. Planned maintenance extends machine life.

Spare parts supply: RNG Export keeps all spare parts in stock. Critical spare parts (blades, bearings, screens) can be supplied within 24 hours.

Technical support: 24/7 technical support line. Troubleshooting via PLC with remote access. Field service.

7. ENERGY EFFICIENCY

Inverter optimization: VFD-controlled motors reduce energy consumption by 15-20% by adjusting speed based on line load.

Smart feeding: Sensor-based feeding system adjusts machine speed based on line load. Idle operation prevented, energy saved.

8. APPLICATION AREAS

Textile fiber: Long hemp fibers used in textile industry. High-quality peeling preserves fiber length.

Composite raw material: Short and long hemp fibers used in composite production. Homogeneous separation increases composite quality.

Construction materials: Hemp fibers used in natural insulation material production. Clean separation determines product quality.

industrial-flax-machinery.title: Industrial Flax Machinery and Applications: Comprehensive Guide
industrial-flax-machinery.excerpt: Machines required for industrial flax processing: decorticator, shaker, aspiration, cottonization, drying, and pressing. Which machine at which stage?
industrial-flax-machinery.content: Industrial flax processing requires an integrated machine park. Each machine plays a critical role at a specific stage of the process.
industrial-flax-machinery.long_content:
Industrial flax processing is a complex process that transforms raw flax stalks from the field into industrial-grade fiber. This process requires many machines working integrated. RNG Export's industrial flax machinery optimizes every stage of this process.

1. BALE OPENING UNIT (RODI)

Function: Opens compressed flax bales from field and brings them to suitable format for line. Performs metal detection and pre-cleaning.

Technical specifications: Automatic bale feeding, magnetic detector, pre-cleaning unit. Capacity: 1-5 tons/hour. RNG Export's RODI series operates up to 5 tons/hour capacity.

Critical points: Fiber breakage must be prevented during bale opening. Low-speed, gentle opening mechanism used.

2. DECORTICATOR

Function: Separates woody part (shive) of flax stalk from fiber. This is the most critical stage of flax processing.

Technical specifications: Adjustable blade angles (10-18°), low speed (400-600 RPM), inverter-controlled motor. Capacity: 500 kg/hour - 5 tons/hour.

Critical points: Preserving fiber integrity is critical. Aggressive processing leads to fiber breakage. Specially designed blade geometry for flax used.

3. SHAKER (VIBRATING) SYSTEMS

Function: Cleans remaining small shive particles after decortication. Multi-stage screen systems used.

Technical specifications: 3-5 stage shaker systems, anti-blinding technology, VFD drive. Screen sizes: 2-10 mm range.

Critical points: Anti-blinding technology keeps screens continuously open. This way cleaning efficiency does not drop.

4. ASPIRATION UNITS

Function: Removes dust, short fibers, and light particles released during processing from environment. ATEX-compliant systems mandatory.

Technical specifications: Cyclone + bag filter combination, VFD fans, spark detection systems. Flow rate: 5000-30000 m³/hour.

Critical points: Flax dust is flammable. ATEX Zone 22 compliant systems, spark detection and automatic suppression mandatory.

5. COTTONIZATION UNIT

Function: Converts long fibers to short fibers (cottonized fiber). Critical for textile and composite applications.

Technical specifications: Multi-drum system, adjustable blade geometry, low-speed drums (600-900 RPM). Capacity: 500 kg/hour - 3 tons/hour.

Critical points: Fiber length control is critical. Aggressive cottonization leads to fiber breakage. Recipe-based automation provides optimal setting.

6. LONG FIBER LINE

Function: Processes 6-40 cm long fibers preserving them. Critical for composite and high-quality textile applications.

Technical specifications: Low-speed drums, anti-blinding shaker, gentle processing. Fiber length: 6-40 cm.

Critical points: Preserving fiber integrity is critical. Aggressive processing techniques should be avoided.

7. DRYING UNIT

Function: Brings moisture content of processed flax fiber to 8-12% band. Over-drying reduces fiber quality.

Technical specifications: Belt or drum dryers, online moisture sensors, VFD-controlled fans. Temperature: 60-80°C.

Critical points: Online moisture sensors provide continuous measurement. Over-drying prevented, product quality preserved.

8. PRESSING UNIT

Function: Presses processed flax fiber into high-density bales. Reduces logistics costs.

Technical specifications: Hydraulic press, automatic bale tying, high density (400-600 kg/m³). Capacity: 1-5 tons/hour.

Critical points: Fiber breakage must be prevented during pressing. Controlled pressure applied.

9. AUTOMATION AND CONTROL

PLC system: All machines controlled via central PLC system. Recipe-based production enables quick changeover.

SCADA system: SCADA system in advanced facilities monitors and reports entire process. Energy monitoring, quality control integration.

Quality control: Online moisture, shive ratio, fiber length measurement systems. Automatic warning when outside target band.

10. INTEGRATION AND EFFICIENCY

Line integration: All machines work integrated. Problem in one machine does not affect entire line. Modular design provides flexibility.

Energy optimization: VFD-controlled motors reduce energy consumption by 15-20% by adjusting speed based on line load.

Maintenance planning: Preventive maintenance program extends machine life and prevents unplanned downtime. RNG Export provides planned maintenance service with maintenance agreements.

footer.brand_text: Your global engineering partner in flax and hemp fiber processing technologies. From field to final product, we deliver 100% expertise and efficiency-driven solutions.

q1.question: Who are hemp machine manufacturers?
q1.answer: RNG Export is an engineering company that manufactures cottonization, decorticator, peeling and fiber opening machines for hemp and flax fiber processing.

q2.question: What products are obtained with flax processing machines?
q2.answer: Long fiber, short fiber, cottonized fiber and biocomposite raw materials are produced from flax and hemp.

q3.question: What lines are found in a turnkey fiber plant?
q3.answer: It includes bale opening, decorticator, aspiration, cottonization, long fiber line, drying, pressing and automation integration.

q4.question: What is the difference between flax and hemp processing machines?
q4.answer: Flax fibers are finer and more delicate, requiring lower speeds and gentler openers. Hemp is tougher and needs higher crushing power in the decorticator. RNG Export lines offer the flexibility to process both products on a single line thanks to inverter-controlled motors and interchangeable knife sets.

q5.question: What is the cost of a turnkey fiber plant installation?
q5.answer: The cost varies depending on capacity (tons/hour), automation level, and selected machine configuration. We offer scalable solutions ranging from 1 ton/hour starter lines to 5 ton/hour fully automated integrated facilities. You can contact our engineers for detailed feasibility and price offers.

q6.question: How is decorticator machine efficiency measured?
q6.answer: Decorticator efficiency is measured by the ratio of woody parts (shives) separated without fiber loss. A good decorticator should provide 80-90% cleaning without breaking the fiber. RNG Export decorticators offer minimum fiber loss and maximum cleaning with adjustable knife angles and an optimized feeding system.
